subject: Re: [junit] Alphabetizing test method run order?
msgSnippet: Hmm... I think it would be even better to _ensure_ that the test cases are run in a random order but provide a summary at the end of the testrun where the
messageBody:
Hmm... I think it would be even better to _ensure_ that the test cases are
run
in a random order but provide a summary at the end of the testrun where the
order gets printed.
In that way, people would be urged to create independent tests and if it
happens
that the tests are not independent (and this is discovered through a
different ordering)
they can diagnose the problem and fix their tests.



On Tue, Sep 20, 2011 at 10:10 AM, Stephen Connolly <
stephen.alan.connolly@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> At present if you create a Request, the tests will be unsorted, but you can
> call
>
> Request r;
> r.sort( new Comparator() { ... } );
>
> to have the tests sorted.
>
> Additionally, a Runner has the ability to sort its tests initially,
> though IMHO there is a tad missing in terms of sorting if your Runner
> extends from ParentRunner as the entire list of tests is hidden from
> the Sortable interface and child classes of ParentRunner... thus you
> are relying on Collections.sort to establish your sorting with the
> comparator.
>
> i.e. Some sorting requirements may need as many as N*N/2 comparisons
> to establish the correct sorting, while Collections.sort will
> typically only perform N*log(N) comparisons.
>
> See https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/pull/316
>
> Something similar to https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/pull/316 will
> probably be needed if/as more people use the Request#sort(Comparator)
> method.
>
> On 20 September 2011 08:44, Malte Finsterwalder
>
> <malte@...> wrote:
> > +1
> >
> > keep ordering undefined.
> > Allow ordering though a custom Annotation, a Runner or a Rule (or a
> > combination thereof, whatever makes sense).
> >
> >
> > ------------------------------------
> >
> > Yahoo! Groups Links
> >
> >
> >
> >
>
>
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
